result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Hearing on November 28, 2022 at 08:30 am.

8:34 AM Defendant Meguel A Watts in court, in custody.  Attorney Peter M Wolff in court for Meguel A Watts.  Prosecuting attorney Melissa J. Zilavy in court for the State of Wisconsin. Victim rights have been complied with by the Waukesha County District Attorneys Office. 

Case called for bail/bond hearing. 

Defense makes arguments in support of motion to lower cash bail an/or a signature bond. 
The State makes arguments in opposition to any modification of cash bond. 

For reasons stated on the record, the Court denies the Motion for Bail Modification. 

Atty Wolff requests to set case 22cf1399 for jury trial and status following speedy trial demand. 

Court will set for jury trial and jury status on 22CF1399, other cases to follow.
Hearing scheduled for December 6, 2022 at 08:30 am.

Defendant to comply with I.D. Processing.  Defendant to have no contact with witness A listed in the Criminal Complaint/Victim Identification Key.  Defendant is not to share, reproduce or distribute any personal and/or identifying information about the crime victim(s), except to their attorney.    Absolute sobriety, defendant is not to possess or consume any alcohol.  Defendant is not to use/possess any controlled substances without a valid prescription and take as prescribed.  Defendant not to possess any drug paraphernalia.
